metadata.case_name: Railway Board v. Proprietor of The Indian Observer

facts.text: The respondent was the owner and publisher of a weekly newspaper known as The Indian Observer with weekly circulation of approximately 1,35,000 copies.
Till March 1965, The Indian Observer was being sold at all railway stations managed by the Railway Board.
The policy of The Indian Observer was to publish constructive criticism and fair comment in public interest on Government departments, including maladministration in Railways.
In issue dated 11th September 1964, allegations made about black-marketing in deluxe train tickets by Railway staff, described as a big racket and corruption.

On 22nd September 1964, Circulation Manager of petitioner company received letter from M/s Gulab Singh & Ltd., licensee, intimating ban by Northern Railways Administration on sale at Railway Book Stalls.
General Manager, Northern Railways, informed temporary permission given to contractors subject to review, asked for copies of 12 old issues which were supplied.
On 16th March 1965, informed that sale of The Indian Observer would not be permitted on railway stations.
In return by Joint Director, Traffic General, Railway Board, denied sale at stations, alleged sexy and obscene literature of low taste, not due to corruption articles.
Delhi High Court in C.W. No. 197-D of 1965 dated August 11, 1965 allowed writ petition, set aside ban as discriminatory and without authority under clause 742 of Indian Railway Code.

Book stalls belong to licensees under agreement with President of India; clause 3(b) allows licensor to require sale of specified publications; clause 5 allows prohibiting obscene/scurrilous publications, decision final.
Railway Board letter dated March 26, 1965 stated Indian Observer contained articles of low taste bordering on obscenity, not fit for sale at stations, instructed contractors to stop sale.
High Court found publications freely sold on stalls hardly distinguishable from Indian Observer on obscenity grounds.
Indian Observer sold on platforms since 1963.

legal_issues.text: Whether the ban imposed by Railway Board on sale of The Indian Observer at railway book stalls was discriminatory and violative of Article 14 of the Constitution.
Whether Railway Board had authority under licence agreements and clause 742 of Indian Railway Code to impose ban without prior Government prohibition on obscene publications.
Whether respondent had locus standi to challenge the ban under Article 14, given platforms are railway property.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sale regulated by licence agreements; clause 5 allows prohibiting obscene/scurrilous publications; Railway platforms private property, no right to insist on sale.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Licence agreement clauses 3(b), 5; Railway Board v. Niranjan Singh

petitioner_arguments.text: Action taken per letter dated March 26, 1965 as publication not fit for sale due to low taste bordering obscenity; respondent no locus standi.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Railways Act s.120A; Indian Railway Code clause 742

petitioner_arguments.text: 'Government' in clause 742(v) means Railway Board per s.2 Indian Railway Board Act 1905.

respondent_arguments.text: Ban discriminatory under Art.14 as similar publications sold freely; singled out despite clause 742 requiring equal opportunity and ban only on govt-prohibited obscene publications.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art.14; Indian Railway Code clause 742

respondent_arguments.text: Railway Board not authorised to ban on own determination of obscenity; ban not on ground of govt prohibition.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Railways Act s.28; Indian Railway Code clause 742

court_reasoning.text: Ban letter did not state prohibition on obscenity grounds or prior govt order; clause 742(v) requires govt prohibition for obscene ban; Indian Observer singled out, discriminatory.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No finding of obscenity or govt prohibition; violates equal opportunity in clause 742(viii).

court_reasoning.text: Railway Board is 'State' under Art.12; platforms accessible to public unlike internal premises; respondent challenges discriminatory order affecting equal sale policy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.14 applicable to administrative order directing licensees to discriminate without legal basis.

court_reasoning.text: Railway Board v. Niranjan Singh inapplicable as platforms not analogous to workshops/offices; no fundamental right enforcement but challenge to discriminatory directive.
No need to decide s.28 applicability given Art.14 violation.

holdings.text: Impugned order of Railway Board discriminatory, without authority under clause 742, violative of Art.14.
Railway Board cannot ban publications on own obscenity determination absent govt prohibition per clause 742.
Respondent can invoke Art.14 against discriminatory administrative order.

precedents_cited.relevance: No fundamental right to hold meetings on railway premises; inapplicable to public access platforms and discriminatory sale ban.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Railway Board is State; ban discriminatory violating equality; challengeable via writ.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railways Act, 1890
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits under-preference; prior rules on licensing sales; punishes unlicensed hawking.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railway Board Act, 1905
statutes_cited.relevance: Central Govt may invest powers in Railway Board; but no authority to prohibit sales independently.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railway Code (Traffic Dept. Commercial)
statutes_cited.relevance: Ban obscene/govt-prohibited publications; equal opportunity to popular newspapers.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court judgment upheld quashing the ban on sale of The Indian Observer at railway book stalls as discriminatory under Art.14 and without authority.

key_quotes.text: "the Indian Observer had been singled out for being banned and this clearly amounted to a discriminatory treatment."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The contractor should provide equal opportunity to all the popular newspapers for sale in their stalls on the same terms."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes clause 742(viii) policy breached by ban.

key_quotes.text: "Railway platforms may be the property of the railways, but it cannot be disputed that every bona fide traveller or every other member of the public who buys a platform ticket can have access."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies public nature, applicability of Art.14.
